boat.full_description:
Externally Polly Agatha is an exact replica of the 1903 Bristol Channel Pilot Cutter Peggy, which is still sailing.

All of the scantlings are the same as the original and the method of construction of the hull is also the same with only two exceptions. One is the use of bronze bolts and screws instead of the original iron centre line fixings and bronze nails for the planking to frame fixings.

Another difference is the deck. Polly Agatha's consists of two layers of marine plywood sheathed in epoxy and glass overlaid with 3 inch wide teak. This was chosen to increase strength, stiffness and durability.

In building this replica some external features of the original were reintroduced which have been lost on the Peggy, with the intent of enhancing her beautiful lines.

The internal layout is optimised for her intended role as a sea school and finished in solid English oak. The master cabin is luxurious with an en-suite head and shower. There is a traditional head in the bow and a forward cabin with two berths and two extra occasional berths. The saloon has another four berths including two occasional on the saloon seats, providing a total of ten berths.

There is a large galley and navigational area fully equipped with modern technology including everything needed to licence the boat as a sea school.
